abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Chromosomal rearrangements act as barriers to gene flow and can thus promote speciation. In moths and butterflies (Lepidoptera), which possess holocentric chromosomes facilitating karyotype changes, chromosome fusions are more common than fissions. Yet, limited evidence suggests that when speciation involves chromosomal rearrangements, it is most often linked to fissions. Notable karyotypic variation is observed in three clades of the subfamily Polyommatinae (Lycaenidae), with chromosome numbers ranging from n = 10 to 225. We investigated genome sizes and karyotypes in several species of the genera Polyommatus and Lysandra with modal and derived high chromosome numbers. Our findings showed no support for polyploidy, confirming previous conclusions about karyotypic diversification via chromosome fragmentation in this butterfly family. Species with high chromosome numbers have slightly larger genomes, which indicate a potential role of repetitive sequences but contradict the hypothesis of holocentric drive. Ends of fragmented chromosomes were healed with telomeres synthesized de novo, which were significantly larger than those of species with modal karyotype. No interstitial telomeric sequences were detected on autosomes. Internal telomeric signals on sex chromosomes, however, revealed multiple sex chromosome systems in Polyommatus (Plebicula) dorylas and Polyommatus icarus, with two karyotype races differing in sex chromosome constitution in the latter. Notably, the W chromosome resisted fragmentation, presumably due to its epigenetic silencing.

boxed-text.label: Significance
boxed-text.p: Chromosomal rearrangements can drive reproductive isolation, but direct evidence remains limited. Blue butterflies in the genus Polyommatus exhibit exceptionally high diversification rates alongside an extraordinary range of chromosome numbers (n = 10 to 225). This study confirms that their high chromosome numbers result from extensive chromosomal fragmentation rather than polyploidy, with the W sex chromosome remaining intact, likely due to its epigenetic repression. Notably, the study shows that fragmented chromosomes are not only stabilized through telomere restoration but also exhibit a hypertrophic increase in telomere size. These findings highlight strategies to maintain genomic integrity amidst profound karyotypic changes and underscore the importance of two regions often misrepresented in genome assemblies, sex chromosomes, and telomeres, in genome evolution and speciation.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Chromosomal rearrangements may play a crucial role in speciation, as they can serve as barriers to gene flow (Faria and Navarro 2010). Theoretical models of chromosomal speciation have traditionally concerned monocentric chromosomes (Baker and Bickham 1986; Yoshida and Kitano 2021), which have a localized centromeric region. However, holocentric chromosomes, lacking a distinct centromere, may facilitate karyotype change and thus potentially impact the process of speciation (Lucek et al. 2022). Holocentric chromosomes have evolved multiple times and represent a significant portion of biodiversity (Drinnenberg et al. 2014; Escudero et al. 2016; Marques and Drinnenberg 2025).

Moths and butterflies (Lepidoptera), comprising more than 160,000 species (Van Nieukerken et al. 2011), represent the most species-rich holocentric lineage. Only about 1.5% of species have been karyotyped (De Vos et al. 2020), and only a small fraction has been analyzed in detail beyond simple chromosome counts. This is largely due to uniformity of their small metaphase chromosomes that complicated identification of individual chromosomes (De Prins and Saitoh 2003). Recent advances in sequencing technologies have provided robust phylogenetic framework and have brought genomes to chromosome level, thus offering an unprecedented opportunity to better understand the role of chromosomal changes in lepidopteran speciation (Augustijnen et al. 2024; Wright et al. 2024).

Lepidopteran genome organization, including synteny of genes, is highly conserved across distant lineages (De Vos et al. 2020; Wright et al. 2024). The most frequent chromosome number n = 31 is also ancestral (Van't Hof et al. 2013; Traut et al. 2023; Wright et al. 2024), and extensive karyotype changes are limited only to few groups (De Vos et al. 2020; Wright et al. 2024). Phylogenetic analyses of diversification indicated a positive association between speciation rates and changes in chromosome numbers in Lepidoptera (Talavera et al. 2013a; De Vos et al. 2020; Augustijnen et al. 2024). Although chromosome fusions are more common than fissions, cladogenetic chromosomal changes associated with speciation events mostly correspond to fissions (De Vos et al. 2020; Augustijnen et al. 2024).

Blue butterflies of the family Lycaenidae possess the greatest interspecific karyotype variation of all animals with chromosome numbers ranging from n = 10 to 225 (Kandul et al. 2004) and no evidence of polyploidization (Kandul et al. 2007; Wright et al. 2024). Their modal chromosome number was first reduced to n = 24 in the lycaenid last common ancestor (Robinson 1971; Wright et al. 2024). The majority of blue butterflies with derived chromosome numbers belong to three closely related lineages within the subtribe Polyommatina, the genus Lysandra (n = 24 to 93), and the subgenera Agrodiaetus (n = 10 to 125) and Plebicula (n = 134 to 225), which are now classified under the genus Polyommatus (Kandul et al. 2004; Talavera et al. 2013a). Intraspecific variation in chromosome number has been reported as well. For example, n = 87 to 88 was observed in Spanish, French, and Italian populations of Lysandra coridon, while specimens from the Balkans and Greece possess n = 90 to 93 chromosomes (De Lesse 1969; Coutsis et al. 2001). Kandul et al. (2004) hypothesized that karyotypic diversification in the subgenus Agrodiaetus (n = 10 to 125) was due to the activity of mobile elements horizontally transferred between the closely related species. Comparative phylogenetic analysis in the subgenus Agrodiaetus showed that chromosomal numbers are more diverse between young sympatric species than in corresponding allopatric pairs. This implies that chromosomal rearrangements play a direct role in the speciation process (Kandul et al. 2007). Likewise, an increase in the diversification rate was confirmed in Lysandra spp. (Kandul et al. 2007; Talavera et al. 2013b). However, phylogenetic comparative analyses of karyotype evolution in Agrodiaetus spp. by Vershinina and Lukhtanov (2017) revealed a correlation between the amount of karyotype differences and the length of phylogenetic branches, which is not consistent with chromosome rearrangements being associated with cladogenetic events.

Interestingly, two large chromosomes have been observed in species with high chromosome numbers, such as Polyommatus (Agrodiaetus) damone or Polyommatus (Plebicula) atlantica (Lukhtanov et al. 1997; Lukhtanov 2015). According to Ennis (1976), these large chromosomes result from autosomal fusions, while White (1946) argued that the large chromosomes observed in blue butterflies with high chromosome numbers correspond to sex chromosomes. Indeed, comparative genomics show that the sex chromosome Z remains intact in lineages with extensive chromosome fragmentation (Wright et al. 2024). Moreover, unlike in female heterogametic vertebrates (Pennell et al. 2015), sex chromosome–autosome fusions giving rise to large neo-sex chromosomes are quite common in Lepidoptera, including representatives of the family Lycaenidae (Carabajal Paladino et al. 2019; Pazhenkova and Lukhtanov 2023; Wright et al. 2024). It has recently been shown that sex chromosome turnovers may be driven by sexual antagonistic selection (Mora et al. 2024). Yet, sex chromosomes remain generally understudied in female heterogametic taxa (Ellegren 2011; Tomaszkiewicz et al. 2017), and particularly the female-limited W chromosomes are not well represented in lepidopteran chromosome-level assemblies due to their high repeat content and lower sequencing depth compared to autosomes (Carey et al. 2022; Wright et al. 2024).

In this study, we analyzed representatives of the genera Polyommatus and Lysandra (Fig. 1), which vary widely in their chromosomal numbers. Specifically, we examined Polyommatus icarus, Polyommatus escheri and Polyommatus thersites, with a modal chromosome number of n = 23/24 (Robinson 1971; Kandul et al. 2004; Nguyen et al. 2010) and species with high chromosome numbers, namely Lysandra bellargus (n = 45; Nguyen et al. 2010), Lysandra coridon (n = 87 to 93; De Lesse 1969), Lysandra hispana (n = 84; Descimon and Mallet 2010), Polyommatus (Agrodiaetus) ripartii (n = 90; Munguira et al. 1995), Polyommatus (Agrodiaetus) fulgens (n = 103; Munguira et al. 1995), and P. (Plebicula) dorylas (n = 149 to 151; Wiemers 2003). To directly test whether polyploidization played a role in their karyotype evolution, we determined their genome sizes and confirmed that high chromosome numbers result from chromosomal fragmentation rather than polyploidy. To investigate whether sex chromosomes resist fragmentation, we further performed molecular cytogenetic analyses of P. icarus, P. escheri, L. bellargus, L. coridon, and P. (Plebicula) dorylas. Indeed, we found that the W sex chromosome is resistant to fissions and instead fused with autosomes in P. icarus and P. (Plebicula) dorylas. Moreover, we showed that fragmented chromosomes are not only stabilized through telomere restoration but also exhibit a hypertrophic increase in telomere size.

sec.title: Genome Size
sec.p: We measured the 2C values of nine blue butterfly species using flow cytometry. The resulting genome sizes with mean and standard deviation are shown in Table 1 along with the published karyotypes. The genome sizes of tested species range from 0.62 to 0.82 pg, with species with higher chromosome numbers exhibiting larger genomes. However, the difference in genome size is no more than 32%. Based on these results, we can conclude that the increase in chromosome number in Lycaenidae did not result from polyploidization but rather from chromosomal fissions.

sec.title: Cytogenetic Analyses
sec.p: We aimed to determine the chromosome number of five species, namely P. icarus, P. escheri, L. bellargus, L. coridon, and P. (Plebicula) dorylas. The diploid chromosome number was counted from mitotic chromosomal preparations, which were stained by DAPI (4′,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole) in DABCO (1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane). We confirmed the diploid chromosome number 2n = 46 in P. icarus males (Fig. S1d and f), while in females, the number varied between individuals, ranging from 2n = 45 to 2n = 46 (Fig. S1c and e). We were not able to reliably count the chromosomes for P. escheri due to insufficient number of chromosomal preparations, although two overlapping mitotic complements (Fig. S2a) support the published chromosome number 2n = 46 (Robinson 1971). In species with karyotypes resulting from a high number of fissions, we were unable to determine the chromosome numbers from our spread nuclei. Therefore, we rely on chromosome numbers reported in the literature (Table 1), even though these numbers belong to specimens from different populations.

Female sex chromosome bivalents can be detected through differential chromomere patterns produced by staining of female pachytene complements with 2.5% lactic acetic orcein (LAO) (Suppl. Text and Fig. S3; cf. Traut 1976). However, for more reliable detection of W chromosome, we used genomic in situ hybridization (GISH) on female spread chromosome preparations (Fig. 2; Figs. S1 and S2). When compared to the chromomere pattern after staining with LAO, GISH signals generally highlighted the same regions of W chromosomes. GISH confirmed that the sex chromosomes are the largest elements in all tested species except for P. escheri. Mitotic nuclei of females of P. icarus, L. bellargus, and L. coridon carry two large sex chromosomes (Figs. S1c and d and S2b to d). Interestingly, in female mitotic nuclei of P. (Plebicula) dorylas, we observed three large chromosomes, with the W chromosome being markedly larger than the other two (Fig. S2d). In contrast, male mitotic nuclei displayed two large chromosome pairs (Fig. S2e). This observation implies that the largest W chromosome pairs with two Z chromosomes, thus constituting a WZ1Z2 multiple sex chromosome system. To confirm that the W chromosome is generally the largest element in fragmented lepidopteran karyotypes, we performed GISH on Calliteara pudibunda (2n = 174; Robinson 1971). In agreement with previous reports (Robinson 1971), mitotic nuclei comprised four large chromosomes, likely corresponding to two chromosome pairs. The largest chromosome was identified as the W chromosome, as it was clearly highlighted by the female genomic probe (Fig. S4).

sec.p: As mentioned above, in P. icarus, the W sex chromosomes varied between females with different chromosome numbers. In all tested specimens with 2n = 45, GISH labeled solely the interstitial part of W chromosome in pachytene nuclei (Figs. 2b and 3b; Fig. S1b). The same pattern was observed in mitotic nuclei (Fig. S1e) and after staining by LAO (Fig. S3b). In females with 2n = 46, GISH labeled half of the W chromosome (Figs. 2a and 3a; Fig. S1a and c), suggesting the presence of karyotypic races differing in their sex chromosome constitution. Since sex chromosomes in P. icarus appear to be associated with the nucleolar-organizing region (NOR) (Figs. 2a and b and 3a and b), we performed fluorescence in situ hybridization with the 18S rDNA probe (Suppl. Text and Fig. S1).

Arrowheads point to internal telomeric signals marking the ends of Z1 and Z2 chromosomes paired with the W chromosome in a trivalent. Insets in a), b), and f) show combined GISH with female gDNA labeled by Cy3-dUTP or fluorescein-dUTP (red). a) P. icarus with 2n = 46, WZ, b) P. icarus with 2n = 45, WZ1Z2, c) P. escheri, d) L. bellargus, e) L. coridon, and f) P. (Plebicula) dorylas. Telomeric signals are present at the ends of all chromosomes in each species. Internal telomeric signals were observed in sex chromosome multivalents in one of the two karyotypic races of P. icarus (b) and in P. (Plebicula) dorylas (f). Scale bar. 10 μm.

sec.p: The results of GISH also revealed a considerable difference between the W chromosomes of P. icarus and P. escheri (Fig. 2a and c) (Table 1). Unlike in P. icarus, the entire W chromosome of P. escheri was highlighted by the female genomic probe. Moreover, we observed peculiar pairing between the W and Z sex chromosomes, with the larger Z chromosome wrapping around the smaller W chromosome (Fig. 2c; Suppl. Text and Figs. S1g and S3c). In both, L. coridon and L. bellargus, we observed DAPI-positive block at one end of their sex chromosome bivalents, which was not labeled by the female genomic probe. Although LAO stained more or less the entire length of their W chromosomes, the female genomic probe labeled only about two thirds of their W chromosomes in both species (Fig. 2d to e). In P. (Plebicula) dorylas, the female genomic probe strongly hybridized mainly to the interstitial part of the W chromosome, similar to the LAO staining pattern, with more interspersed signals along the rest of the W (Figs. 2f and 3; Fig. S1j).

After GISH, chromosomal preparations were reprobed with fluorescence in situ hybridization with the (TTAGG)n telomeric probe (telo-FISH) to test for the presence of telomeric sequences and identify sex chromosome multivalents in species with high chromosome numbers. Telomeric sequences were confirmed at both ends of all chromosomes in all tested species, indicating their de novo synthesis following chromosomal fragmentation (Fig. 3). Compared to their relatives with modal karyotypes, telomeric signals seemed to be stronger in L. coridon and P. (Plebicula) dorylas, which have high chromosome numbers (Fig. 3e and f). To verify this, we detected telomeres on chromosomes of P. icarus, L. coridon, and P. (Plebicula) dorylas in a single telo-FISH experiment using the same hybridization mix. The results were documented with the same exposure time. The minimum exposure time required to detect telomeres in P. icarus resulted in overexposure in L. coridon and P. (Plebicula) dorylas. These results confirmed that the latter two species with fragmented chromosomes have much longer telomeres than P. icarus with modal chromosome number (Fig. S5). To quantify this difference, we performed image analysis. However, we could not compare signal intensities as the signals were saturated in L. coridon and P. (Plebicula) dorylas. Instead, we compared the average area of telomere signals as a proxy for telomere length. We found significant differences in telomere signal areas among species (Kruskal–Wallis, P < 0.0001). Post hoc tests showed that P. icarus significantly differs from L. coridon and P. (Plebicula) dorylas in its telomere signal area (P < 0.05; Fig. 4).

Species significantly differ in their telomere signal areas (Kruskal–Wallis, P < 0.0001). Post hoc tests show significant differences between P. icarus and the other species, L. coridon and P. (Plebicula) dorylas (P < 0.05).

sec.p: Moreover, we detected telomeric signals located within paired sex chromosomes in two species, namely the P. icarus karyotypic race with 2n = 45 (Fig. 3b) and P. (Plebicula) dorylas (Fig. 3f). In P. icarus, telomeric signals were located at the boundary between the euchromatic region, which did not carry a nucleolar- organizing region (NOR), and the interstitial heterochromatic region of the W chromosome highlighted by the female genomic probe (Fig. 3b). These findings, combined with the difference in chromosome number between males and females and the presence of the additional euchromatic region on the W chromosome (Fig. 2a and b), imply that these internal signals do not represent classical interstitial telomeric sequences (ITSs). Rather, the telomeric probe labeled the ends of two Z chromosomes paired in a trivalent with the W chromosome, resulting from a sex chromosome–autosome fusion (cf. Yoshido et al. 2005). This supports the presence of a multiple sex chromosome system WZ1Z2 in this karyotypic race of P. icarus. Also, in P. (Plebicula) dorylas, we detected telomeric signals both at the ends and internally within the paired sex chromosomes (Fig. 3f), suggesting the presence of W, Z1, and Z2 chromosomes forming a trivalent. This is consistent with the observation of three large, nonhomologous chromosomes observed in female mitotic nuclei (Fig. S2d). In contrast, only terminal telomeric signals were detected in the paired sex chromosomes of P. escheri (Fig. 3c), L. bellargus (Fig. 3d), and L. coridon (Fig. 3e).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Based on 2- and 4-fold differences in chromosome numbers observed among closely related lycaenid species such as P. icarus (n = 22 to 23), L. bellargus (n = 45), and L. coridon (n = 87 to 93), polyploidy was initially hypothesized as a possible mode of karyotype evolution in these butterflies (Lorković 1941). Previous studies have refuted polyploidy in lycaenids by indirect evidence such as comparison of areas occupied by metaphase I plates, or a negative correlation between chromosome number and their size (Kandul et al. 2007; Pazhenkova and Lukhtanov 2023). More recently, the lengths of genome assemblies and gene syntenies have supported chromosome fragmentation over whole genome duplications in L. bellargus and L. coridon (Lohse et al. 2022; Pazhenkova and Lukhtanov 2023; Vila et al. 2023; Wright et al. 2024). Our study provides the first genome size measurements determined by flow cytometry for representatives of all three polyommatine lineages with high chromosome numbers. These results do not support polyploidy in polyommatine butterflies, although species with high chromosome numbers tend to have slightly larger genomes than their outgroups with ancestral karyotypes (Fig. 1; Table 1). This finding contrasts with the holocentric drive hypothesis, which predicts negative correlation between chromosome number and genome size, as the depletion of transposable elements should be favored when smaller chromosomes preferentially segregate into oocytes in asymmetric female meiosis (Bureš and Zedek 2014). Indeed, recent research on the Leptidea wood white butterflies suggests that meiotic drive does not facilitate karyotype evolution but rather opposes chromosome fusions, thereby stabilizing lepidopteran karyotypes (Boman et al. 2024).

While the chromosome-level assemblies of L. bellargus, L. coridon, and P. icarus were 0.54 pg, 0.55 pg and 0.52 pg, respectively (Lohse et al. 2022, 2023; Vila et al. 2023), flow cytometry estimated the genome sizes to be higher, at 0.66 pg, 0.70 pg, and 0.63 pg, respectively. Flow cytometry is considered a more reliable approach compared to sequence-based methods (Pflug et al. 2020). This discrepancy suggests that even genome assemblies built using long reads may underestimate genome sizes (cf. Mora et al. 2024). Given that differences in genome sizes are largely driven by repetitive sequences (Talla et al. 2017; Hebert et al. 2019; Pazhenkova and Lukhtanov 2023), the observed increase in genome sizes in species with fragmented karyotypes may point to a role of repetitive DNA in the karyotypic diversification of Lysandra and Polyommatus spp. (Dalíková et al. 2023; Cabral-de-Mello et al. 2024). However, even in our small sampling, we observed considerable differences in genome sizes of P. (A.) fulgens (Table 1). Indeed, a study on the repeat landscapes in Erebia butterflies showed that repeat composition can vary greatly within species, and this variation scales with divergence (Cornet et al., 2024). Further research is needed to confirm whether the increase in genome size can be ascribed to the activity of horizontally transferred mobile elements (Kandul et al. 2004).

It was hypothesized that ITSs serve as fission breakpoints facilitating the fragmentation of chromosomes as they can induce and heal chromosome breaks (Pazhenkova and Lukhtanov 2023; Wright et al. 2025). In polyommatine butterflies, telomeres have been so far examined using molecular cytogenetics only in several representatives of the Polyommatus subgenus Agrodiaetus, with chromosome numbers ranging from n = 10 to n = ca. 108 (Vershinina et al. 2015). However, telomeric signals were weak and difficult to distinguish from background noise, especially in species with high chromosome numbers. This difficulty was supposedly due to the small size of mitotic chromosomes, which are at the limit of resolution of light microscopy (Vershinina et al. 2015). Pachytene bivalents provided much better resolution, revealing clear telomeric signals at the ends of chromosomes even in Lysandra spp. and P. (Plebicula) dorylas with high chromosome numbers (Fig. 3). In the chromosome-level assemblies of L. bellargus and L. coridon, telomeric repeats were not found in about 10% of chromosomes (Pazhenkova and Lukhtanov 2023). Our results support the hypothesis that these pseudochromosomes are truncated, as we observed clear telomeric signals at the ends of nearly all chromosomes (Fig. 3d and e). Interestingly, compared to their relatives with modal karyotypes, telomeric signals were stronger in L. coridon and P. (Plebicula) dorylas, both of which have high chromosome numbers (Figs. 3e and f and 4; Fig. S5). This suggests increased activity of telomerase, which heals chromosome ends by synthesizing telomeres de novo. Indeed, in the Bombyx mori pSm strain, it was demonstrated that the ends of chromosome fragment induced by X-ray irradiation were healed through de novo addition of (TTAGG)n repeats, which are crucial for stable transmission of such fragments. However, in the Zem B. mori strain, one end of the fragment failed to heal even after more than 40 years (Fujiwara et al. 2000). This contrasts with the holocentric plant Luzula elegans (Juncaceae), which was shown to restore telomeres at fragment ends within 3 weeks after irradiation (Jankowska et al. 2015), suggesting that baseline telomerase activity may be low in Lepidoptera. It has been proposed that telomere elongation could be adaptive (Gómez-Blanco et al. 2023). Since cladogenetic chromosomal changes in butterflies are mostly associated with fissions (Augustijnen et al. 2024), we hypothesize that the ability to restore and elongate telomeric sequences facilitates chromosomal fissions in Lepidoptera and may allow their diversification.

We failed to reliably detect any autosomal ITS reported in L. bellargus and L. coridon (Pazhenkova and Lukhtanov 2023), which is not surprising, as the length of these ITSs seems to be <1.5 kb (Pazhenkova and Lukhtanov 2023), which is below detection threshold of conventional FISH protocols (Speel et al. 2000; Carabajal Paladino et al. 2014). However, we detected internal telomeric signals within the paired sex chromosomes of P. icarus females with 2n = 45 (Fig. 3b) and P. (Plebicula) dorylas females (Fig. 3f), which indicate a sex chromosome trivalent WZ1Z2 originating from sex chromosome–autosome fusions (cf. Yoshido et al. 2005). Such neo-sex chromosome systems are common in Lepidoptera (eg Carabajal Paladino et al. 2019; Gasparotto et al. 2022; Mora et al. 2024; Wright et al. 2024). Several independent Z-autosome fusions have been reported from chromosome-level assemblies of several lycaenids, including L. coridon and P. icarus (Pazhenkova and Lukhtanov 2023; Wright et al. 2025). The results suggest that the previously reported P. icarus fusion was formed between the Z chromosome and an autosome-bearing arrays of rDNA, which is Z-linked in P. icarus females with both 2n = 45 and 2n = 46 (Fig. S1a to f). We assume a corresponding fusion occurred between the W chromosome and the autosome, resulting in a neo-W chromosome with one euchromatic region (Figs. 2a and 3a) and possibly involving loss of the rDNA cluster. This neo-sex chromosome system appears to be widespread, as it is shared between Scottish (Lohse et al. 2023) and Czech P. icarus populations and could thus be up to 2 My old (cf. Dincă et al. 2011). However, another fusion occurred only between the neo-W chromosome and another autosome in the Czech population, giving rise to the observed multiple sex chromosome system with an additional euchromatic region on the W chromosome and chromosome Z2 (Figs. 2b and 3b). Thus, we observed repeated sex chromosome–autosome fusions resulting in two distinct karyotype races, which make P. icarus an ideal system for future studies of drivers of sex chromosome turnovers (cf. Mora et al. 2024).

Similarly, sex-linked internal telomeric signals (Fig. 3f) and different constitutions of large chromosomes in male and female mitotic complements (Fig. S2d and e) suggest the presence of multiple sex chromosome systems WZ1Z2 in P. (Plebicula) dorylas. The female mitotic complements comprised three distinct large chromosomes, with the largest being the W chromosome (Fig. S2d), while the male karyotype contained two large pairs (Fig. S2e). The hybridization pattern of the female genomic probe in pachytene nuclei suggested that the P. (Plebicula) dorylas W chromosome comprises a highly differentiated interstitial region and two less differentiated regions (Fig. 2f), again indicating the presence of two independent W chromosome–autosome fusions. Interestingly, the internal telomeric signal was located in a region pairing with the highly differentiated part of the W sex chromosome (Fig. 3f), which suggests a fission rather than fusion origin for the Z2 chromosome in P. (Plebicula) dorylas. Further study is needed to discern between these two scenarios. Two large chromosomal pairs were also observed in other species of subgenus Plebicula, namely Polyommatus golgus (2n = 268), Polyommatus nivescence (2n = 382), and P. atlantica (2n = 446) (De Lesse 1970; Lukhtanov 2015; Wright et al. 2025), which suggests that the multiple sex chromosome system occurred in a common ancestor of this lineage. Accordingly, scattered GISH hybridization signals indicate higher level of differentiation of these W chromosome regions (Fig. 2f).

Sex chromosomes must have resisted extensive chromosome fragmentation, as they were clearly the largest elements in the karyotypes of L. bellargus, L. coridon, and P. (Plebicula) dorylas (Fig. S2b to e). The same is true for C. pudibunda (Fig. S4). This contrasts with the autosomes, which were entirely fragmented in P. coridon (Pazhenkova and Lukhtanov 2023; Wright et al. 2024). Moreover, the Z chromosome resists fissions also in other lepidopteran lineages with highly reorganized genomes (Wright et al. 2024, 2025), although it is generally involved in the highest number of fusions (Carabajal Paladino et al. 2019; Wright et al. 2024) and experiences more intrachromosomal rearrangements compared to autosomes (Van't Hof et al. 2013). Similarly, an X chromosome seems to be highly conserved also in beetles (Coleoptera) and aphids and treehoppers (both Hemiptera) (Mathers et al. 2021; Bracewell et al. 2024; Palmer Droguett et al. 2024). Also, the gene content of a mammalian X chromosome was early recognized as evolutionarily highly conserved by Ohno (1966), who proposed that it is constrained by dosage compensation. More recently, it has been suggested that the strong selective constraint is actually imposed by the 3D genomic architecture needed for X chromosome inactivation (Brashear et al. 2021). Moreover, aphid X chromosomes seem to be recalcitrant even to rearrangements with autosomes, which may be crucial for the proper elimination of the X chromosome during male sex determination (Mathers et al. 2021).

However, lepidopteran sex chromosomes can be broken. Species-specific sex chromosome fissions occurred in Leptidea wood white butterflies, yet the resulting elements can still pair into complex multivalents, which segregate properly due to achiasmatic and inverted female meiosis (Lukhtanov et al. 2018; Yoshido et al. 2020). The nonhomologous W and Z chromosomes can pair despite considerable size differences through synaptic adjustment (Marec 1996; Van't Hof et al. 2008). Moreover, the missegregation of W chromosome fragments without sex-determining genes should bear no fitness cost, as shown in the Samia wild silkmoths (Yoshido et al. 2016). Therefore, it is particularly intriguing that the W chromosome shows no evidence of fissions across polyommatine karyotypes, which makes it the most structurally stable chromosome. This suggests that the W chromosome is protected from fissions rather than selectively constrained. Indeed, the B. mori W chromosome is epigenetically repressed in both somatic tissues and germline, except for postpachytene (Traut et al. 2019), and expresses piRNAs that suppress transposable elements (Kawaoka et al. 2011; Hara et al. 2012), possibly acting in cis (cf. Gebert et al. 2021). Hence, we hypothesize that, despite being highly repetitive, the epigenetically silenced W chromosome is less susceptible to fissions. Moreover, its pairing with Z chromosomes or their fragments may bring together their ends, facilitating their repair and proper segregation, and thus contributing to the structural integrity of the Z chromosome. Further research is needed to test these hypotheses. To conclude, our results show slight increase in repeat content, restoration of telomeres with hypertrophic increase in their size, and structural conservation of sex chromosomes in species with fragmented chromosomes. Overall, it seems that the evolutionary stability of sex chromosomes can be a convergent feature resulting from various idiosyncrasies of sex chromosomes.

sec.title: Sample Collecting
sec.p: For FISH experiments, we sampled five representatives of the subfamily Polyommatinae. Adult females of P. icarus, L. bellargus, and L. coridon were collected in the Czech Republic, namely in the surroundings of České Budějovice, in Hády stone quarry in Brno and around Týnčany village in Central Bohemian Region, respectively. Larvae of P. (Plebicula) dorylas species were obtained from Pavel Skála from maintained breeding, which originates from wild stock from the Czech Republic. The last species, P. escheri, was collected in El Brull in the Montseny area, Catalonia, Spain. Hatched larvae from fertilized females were reared on corresponding host plants, Lotus corniculatus for P. icarus, Coronilla varia for L. bellargus and L. coridon, Anthyllis vulneraria for P. (Plebicula) dorylas, and Astragalus monspessulanus for P. escheri, at room temperature and natural day/night regime. For comparison, we also analyzed a pale tussock moth, C. pudibunda (Erebidae), with 2n = 174 (Robinson 1971) reared from the Czech wild stock. Gonads and imaginal disks of fifth instar larvae were used to make chromosomal preparations, and the remaining tissue was frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at −80 °C until DNA extraction.

Estimation of genome size was performed using adult males collected from various locations. Males of P. icarus were collected in Suchdol nad Lužnicí in South Bohemia, Czech Republic, and El Brull in the Montseny mountain range, Catalonia, Spain, along with P. escheri, P. thersites, P. (A.) ripartii and P. (A.) fulgens. P. (Plebicula) dorylas, and P. hispana that were collected from Coll de Pal (Bagà) and Fígols in the Pre-Pyrenees of Catalonia, Spain, respectively. Lysandra coridon was collected in the Hády stone quarry in Brno, Czech Republic. All individuals were frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at −80 °C until further use. As a standard, we used the WT-C laboratory wild-type strain of Ephestia kuehniella (Pyralidae; Marec 1990). Larvae of this species were reared on wheat meal with brewer's yeast under a controlled environment at a temperature of 21 ± 1 °C with a 12/12 h light/dark cycle.

sec.title: Genome Size Estimation
sec.p: We estimated the size of selected blue butterfly's genome using flow cytometry according to Buntrock et al. (2012) with some modifications. Briefly, the head (or half of it) from a single tested specimen and the head of a single E. kuehniella standard (1C = 0.45 pg; Buntrock et al. 2012) were homogenized together in 1 mL of buffer (100 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 2 mM MgCl2, and 1% Triton X-100) using a razor blade. The mixture was then filtered through a 42 µm filter (Uhelon 130 T). Cells were stained with propidium iodide at a final concentration of 50 µg/mL for at least 25 min. Three male samples of each species were prepared independently. Measurements were performed using a Sysmex CyFlow Space flow cytometer equipped with a 100 mW green diode-pumped solid-state laser emitting an exciting light at 532 nm, recording the fluorescence of at least 5,000 particles. Histogram evaluation was carried out using FlowJo software, version 10 (FlowJo, LLC, Ashland, OR, United States). The DNA amount was calculated as the ratio of the 2C mean of the sample to the 2C mean of the E. kuehniella standard, multiplied by the genome size of the standard.

sec.title: Molecular Cytogenetic Analyses
sec.p: Mitotic and meiotic chromosome spreads were prepared from imaginal disks and ovaries of last instar larvae following Mediouni et al. (2004), with slight modifications detailed in Šíchová et al. (2013). The preparations were dehydrated in an ethanol series (70%, 80%, and 100%, 30 to 60 s each) and stored at −80 °C along with the rest of larvae body, which was frozen in liquid nitrogen.

The frozen bodies were later used for DNA extraction using hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) following Winnepenninckx et al. (1993). The extracted male genomic DNA (gDNA) was amplified using the GenomiPhi HY kit (GE Healthcare Limited, Buckinghamshire, United Kingdom) according to the manufacturer’s protocol. The concentration of DNA was measured using a Qubit 3.0 fluorometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, United States).

Telomeric DNA (TTAGG)n was generated using nontemplate polymerase chain reaction (PCR) with two oligomers, 5′-TAGGTTAGGTTAGGTTAGGT-3′ and 5′-CTAACCTAACCTAACCTAAC-3′ (Sahara et al. 1999). Reactions were carried out in 100 µL volumes containing 0.5 µM each of primers, 1× Ex Taq buffer, 0.8 mM dNTP mix, and 2 U Ex Taq polymerase (TaKaRa, Otsu, Japan). The thermal profile of the reaction started with an initial stage of 90 s at 94 °C, followed by 30 cycles of 45 s of denaturation at 94 °C, 30 s of annealing at 52 °C, and 60 s of synthesis at 72 °C. A final synthesis step was carried out for 10 min at 72 °C.

A fragment of the gene for 18S ribosomal RNA was amplified by PCR from DNA of the codling moth, Cydia pomonella, using specific primers 5′-CGATACCGCGAATGGCTCAATA-3′ and 5′-ACAAAGGGCAGGGACGTAATCAAC-3′, following Fuková et al. (2005) with some adjustments. Reactions were carried out in 25 µL volumes containing 10 ng of template DNA, 0.5 µM of each primer, 0.2 mM dNTP mix, 1× Ex Taq buffer, and 2 U Ex Taq polymerase (TaKaRa, Otsu, Japan). The thermal profile started with an initial stage at 94 °C for 3 min, followed by 30 cycles of 1 min of denaturation at 94 °C, 1 min of annealing at 52 °C, and 1 min of synthesis at 72 °C. The final synthesis step was 5 min at 72 °C. Both the obtained telomeric DNA and 18S ribosomal DNA (rDNA) were purified using the Wizard SV Gel and PCR Clean-Up System (Promega, Madison, WI, United States) and quantified using a Qubit 3.0 fluorometer.

Hybridization probes were prepared from female genomic gDNA, (TTAGG)n telomeric DNA, and 18S rDNA. These probes were labeled with fluorochrome Cy3-dUTP (Jenna Bioscience, Jena, Germany), fluorescein-12-dUTP (Jenna Bioscience, Jena, Germany), or biotin-16-dUTP (Hoffmann-La Roche, Basilej, Switzerland) using the nick translation method. The 40 µL reaction mixture contained 2 µg of DNA, 1× nick translation buffer (5 mM Tris-HCl, 0.5 mM MgCl2, 0.0005% BSA, pH 7.5), 10 mM β-mercaptoethanol, 50 µM dATP, 50 µM dCTP, 50 µM dGTP, 10 µM dTTP, 20 µM Cy3-dUTP/fluorescein-12-dUTP/biotin-16-dUTP, 40 U DNA polymerase I (Thermo Fisher Scientific), and 0.01 U DNase I (RNase-free, Thermo Fisher Scientific). The incubation at 15 °C varied according to the input DNA. Genomic DNA was labeled for 3.5 h, while (TTAGG)n telomeric DNA and rDNA were labeled for 1 h. The reaction was stopped by adding 1× loading buffer (50% glycerol, 250 mM ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid, 5.9 mM bromophenol blue).

Some of the chromosomal preparations were stained with 2.5% LAO, 2.5% orcein in 30% acetic acid, and 30% lactic acid) to detect W-specific heterochromatin. After 55 min of incubation at room temperature, the LAO was washed away with distilled water. The preparations were inspected using a Zeiss Axioplan 2 phase microscope (Carl Zeiss, Jena, Germany) equipped with a cooled CDC camera XM10. Subsequently, the immersion oil was removed by incubating the preparations for 1 min in xylene followed by 1 min in benzene, and then washed with distilled water. The incorporated LAO was further washed away by methanol:acetic acid (3:1), allowing the preparations to be used for in situ hybridizations.

For detection of the W sex chromosome, we used GISH with a female whole genome-labeled probe. The experiment followed the approach by Sahara et al. (1999) with some modifications. Firstly, the preparations were treated with RNase A (100 µg/mL) for 1 h at 37 °C and washed twice for 5 min in 2× SSC. The 5× Denhardt’s solution (0.1% Ficoll, 0.1% polyvinylpyrrolidone, and 0.1% bovine serum albumin) was used as the blocking solution in which preparations were incubated for 30 min in a water bath at 37 °C. Chromosomes were denatured by 70% formamide in 2× SSC for 3.5 min at 68 °C and then immediately dehydrated in cold ethanol series. For each slide, we prepared 10 µL of hybridization mix containing 250 ng labeled female gDNA, 3 µg unlabeled competitor DNA, 25 µg sonicated salmon sperm DNA (Sigma-Aldrich, Munich, Germany), 50% formamide, and 10% dextran sulfate in 2× SSC. The competitor DNA was male gDNA, which was first fragmented by incubation for 20 min at 99 °C. The slides were hybridized for 3 d at 37 °C. Posthybridization washes were performed in 1% Triton X-100 in 0.1× SSC for 5 min at 62 °C and 2 min in Ilfotol (HERMAN Technology Limited, Cheshire, United Kingdom) at room temperature. The preparations were counterstained with 0.5 mg/ml DAPI and mounted in antifade based on DABCO.

The same chromosomal preparations were also used for FISH with a (TTAGG)n telomeric probe, following the reprobing protocol described by Nguyen et al. (2013). Cover slips were removed, and the preparations were washed twice in 2× SSC for 5 min each. The chromosomal preparations were then postfixed by incubating in 4% paraformaldehyde in 2× SSC for 10 min at room temperature, followed by three washes in 2× SSC. Simultaneously, the genomic probe was washed, and the chromosomes were denatured by incubating in 50% formamide in 1% Triton X-100 in 0.1× SSC for 10 min at 70 °C. The slides were immediately dehydrated through an ethanol series. The preparations were then ready for 10 µL of new hybridization mix, which consisted of 150 ng labeled (TTAGG)n telomeric probe, 25 μg sonicated salmon sperm DNA (Sigma-Aldrich), 50% formamide, and 10% dextran sulfate in 2× SSC.

Alternatively, chromosomal preparations were reprobed with the 18S rDNA probe. For each slide, we used 10 µL of hybridization mix, containing 30 ng biotin-labeled 18S rDNA, 25 μg of sonicated salmon sperm DNA (Sigma-Aldrich), 50% formamide, and 10% dextran sulfate in 2× SSC. The signal was detected using Cy3-conjugated streptavidin (Jackson ImmunoResearch Laboratories Inc, West Grove, PA, United States) and was enhanced with biotinylated antistreptavidin (Vector Labs Inc, Burlingame, CA, United States). The enhanced signal was detected again with Cy3-conjugated streptavidin, following Fuková et al. (2005).

Hybridization experiments were documented using either the Zeiss Axioplan 2 fluorescent microscope (Carl Zeiss, Jena, Germany) equipped with a cooled CCD camera XM10 using cellSens 1.9 software (Olympus Europa Holding, Hamburg, SRN) or the Leica DM6 B fluorescence microscope (Leica Microsystems, Wetzlar, Germany) equipped with Leica sCMOS Monochrome Camera DFC9000GT, using the Leica Application Suite X (LAS X) imaging software v3.7.3.23245. Digital images were captured separately for each fluorescent dye using appropriate filter and subsequently pseudocolored and superimposed using Adobe Photoshop, version 9.0.

sec.title: Image Analysis of Telomeric Signals
sec.p: To compare telomeric hybridization signals between species with modal and derived karyotypes, we performed FISH with a (TTAGG)n in P. icarus, L. coridon, and P. (Plebicula) dorylas as specified above in one experiment using a common hybridization mix. The experiment was documented using the Leica DM6 B fluorescence microscope with the same exposure time used for all species. Pictures were not adjusted in any way. Since the telomeric signals were saturated in L. coridon, and P. (Plebicula) dorylas, we could not compare signal intensities. Instead, we compared normalized area of telomeric signal. The total area of telomeric signal was calculated for 8 to 9 pachytene nuclei of each species using Fiji (Schindelin et al. 2012) using subtract background with a rolling ball radius of 20 pixels, sliding paraboloid, and auto threshold set using Otsu's threshold clustering algorithm. The total area of telomeres from each nucleus was calculated using analysis of particles. The total area was then averaged by the highest known diploid chromosome number (2n in Table 1) corresponding to the expected number of telomeres in pachytene bivalents. Statistical comparison was performed in RStudio version R-4.4.1. We first tested for normality and homogeneity of variances using the Shapiro–Wilk test and Bartlett test, respectively. To compare the resulting normalized telomeric signals between the three species, we used nonparametric Kruskal–Wallis test with nonparametric post hoc analysis.
